text:
EDF has many challenges to address 
in the upcoming years

First of all, as is well known, we
have the extension of the lifespan

of our plants, something that
will span several decades,

and it’s an absolutely
phenomenal challenge.
We also have the construction

of new nuclear plants, the EPRs,
also in the coming years.
We are a strong player

in decarbonization, and we must provide
new services to our clients.

So, to address all these challenges, 
from a digital perspective, we at EDF
have decided to turn to the Cloud.

We see it as an
opportunity to be mastered.

The Cloud is not just a
technological transformation,

it will also be a
transformation of ways of thinking,

a new, more collaborative
way of working together
and building digital projects.

To do this, we needed a
special system in place:
that’s Cloud Campus.

We decided to build Cloud
Campus by working with AWS,

setting up an AWS Skill Guild, offered
by AWS Training and Certification.

So we ultimately built 10
different learning paths

that allowed us to train
over 500 people,
and actually, many more, because,

in fact, we had over 1,200
participants in different sessions.

So it’s something we had
never done

So it’s something we had
never done

in the digital field at
EDF before.

Cloud Campus has allowed us to
create a core group

of pioneers, this core of pioneers that
exists in each EDF entity,

has been put in contact with each other through Cloud Campus,
we have shared with all the experience,

and it allowed us, quite quickly,
to have a fair adoption

of the technology, to see where we
were ready to use it,
and where we could still improve.

And the peer network has also
spread within each entity,

which has led to the technology
spreading very quickly,

and above all, beyond the technology,
the Cloud culture spread quickly

based on examples we had
carried out.

And this allowed us to have a
solid foundation and now
a rapidly accelerating program.

Thanks to AWS ProServe, we were able
to take a real client approach,
putting the user at the center.

The AWS platform is an
ultra-powerful tool,
so we need to master the platform,
we need to know how it works,

we need to be trained on
this platform.
What was important for us

was to ask AWS ProServe to
teach us all of this.

AWS ProServe won’t
necessarily always be there,

so we also have an
autonomy challenge.

So, for this autonomy, we chose to
rely on Cloud Campus

to train our in-house staff, so
that we have a high level of expertise
on this subject.

An AWS Game Day
is a competition.
A team-based competition,

so today we did one for EDF
with 25 teams

of four people, which
represents about

a hundred people, which is
quite phenomenal.

So it’s about bringing all these teams
together around a central theme.

Today’s theme was frugality
and FinOps.

It’s important; it’s a theme that
today at EDF
we give quite a bit of importance to.

We want to raise awareness and
educate our teams

precisely on the consumption
of services

and resources we deploy on
the Cloud.

The adoption of the Cloud and the
digital transformation

of the EDF Group are like
two puzzle pieces

that come together in service
of our business strategy.

And so, what we did was define
performance criteria

for the transformation, which are
responsiveness, resilience,
and competitiveness.
And through pilot experiences,

we ultimately proved by example
what the Cloud could bring,
and it’s a win across the board.

So we can consider that this Cloud
Campus we built, co-constructed

with AWS Training and Certification,
is a real success, and we’re proud of it.
